dt: used as a function word to introduce the second or last member or the second and each following member of a series of items each of which is negated

dt.t: not done by you {wi}nor{/wi} me {wi}nor{/wi} anyone

dt: used as a function word to introduce and negate a following clause or phrase

usages.pl: Is it {parahw}neither{/parahw} nor or neither or?
pt: Although use with {it}or{/it} is neither archaic nor wrong, {it}neither{/it} is usually followed by {it}nor.{/it} A few commentators think that {it}neither{/it} must be limited in reference to two, but reference to more than two has been quite common for several hundred years.

pt.t: rigid enforcement of antique decorum will help {it}neither{/it} language, literature, nor literati

et: Middle English, contraction of {it}nother{/it} neither, nor, from {it}nother{/it}, pronoun & adjective, neither {ma}{mat|neither|}{/ma}
shortdef: —used as a function word to introduce the second or last member or the second and each following member of a series of items each of which is negated
—used as a function word to introduce and negate a following clause or phrase
homologue containing one less methyl group

dt: {bc}a computer logic {dx_def}see {dxt|logic||1d}{/dx_def} circuit that produces an output that is the inverse {dx_def}see {dxt|inverse:2||3}{/dx_def} of that of an {d_link|OR|OR:1} circuit

shortdef: a computer logic circuit that produces an output that is the inverse of that of an OR circuit

dt: used to give added force to a negative statement

dt.t: We couldn't get him to go along {it}for love nor money{/it}.

shortdef: for anything —used to give added force to a negative statement

dt: {bc}any of numerous cold-blooded strictly aquatic {d_link|craniate|craniate} vertebrates that include the bony fishes and usually the {d_link|cartilaginous|cartilaginous fish} and jawless fishes and that have typically an elongated somewhat spindle-shaped body terminating in a broad caudal {dx_def}see {dxt|caudal||2}{/dx_def} fin, limbs in the form of fins when present at all, and a 2-chambered heart by which blood is sent through {d_link|thoracic|thoracic} gills to be oxygenated
{bc}the flesh of fish used as food
{bc}a person who is caught or is wanted (as in a criminal investigation)
{bc}something that resembles a fish: such as
{bc}a person who is in an unnatural or uncomfortable sphere or situation

dt.t: The country boy felt like a {it}fish out of water{/it} in the big city.
can't deal with that problem now; we've got other {it}fish to fry{/it} right now

dt: {bc}one that does not belong to a particular class or category

dt.t: The movie is {it}neither fish nor fowl{/it}—it's not really a comedy, but it's too light-hearted to be called a drama.
